arm_group.description: Negative pressure wound therapy with PICO (Smith & Nephew)

brief_summary.textblock:
The wound infection rate in the groin after vascular surgery has been denoted to be high
      since the wound surveillance register started in 2005. The current wound infection rate
      based on a validation study was 22.9% (24/105 patients with groin incision(s) between 1
      March to 30 June in 2012). The Deep/superficial infection ratio was 7/17. To prove that PICO
      (negative wound pressure therapy) reduces the wound infection rate with ½ standard
      deviation, 90% power at the 5% significance level, inclusion of 160 patients, 80 patients in
      the PICO Group and the standard dressing group are needed.

clinical_study.brief_title: PICO Above Incisions After Vascular Surgery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients 18 years of age and above

          -  Elective vascular surgery

          -  Groin incision (transverse or longitudinal)

          -  Capable of understanding the study information and giving written informed consent

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Emergency surgery

intervention.intervention_name: Negative pressure wound therapy with PICO (Smith & Nephew)

facility.name: Vascular Centre, Malmö, Skåne University Hospital

clinical_study.official_title: PICO Versus Standard Dressing Above Groin Incisions After Vascular Surgery - a Prospective Randomized Trial

overall_official.affiliation: Vascular Centre, Malmö, Skåne University Hospital

oversight_info.authority: Sweden: The National Board of Health and Welfare

primary_outcome.time_frame: Wounds will be checked at 1 year of follow-up

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Costs will be checked at 1 year of follow-up

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Investigator), Primary Purpose: Prevention
